comments:
We've had at least four different people run into a problem where an installed 
JRE is missing libraries. In some cases it's been with the default "eclipse" 
JRE, and other times it has been when the user tries to install their own JRE. 
There does not appear to be anything different with the JREs that exhibit this 
problem (they are usually IBM JREs, but they work on other machines and 
workspaces), and deleting and recreating the Installed JRE doesn't change 
anything. However, pointing to another JRE, reinstalling, or using a new 
workspace usually gets around the problem. The problem will typically show up 
as compile errors (can't find java.lang.Object) in Java projects that use the 
JRE to compile.

The problem seems to be in the detection of the default libraries. For 
instance, it will usually pick up a partial list from jre/lib/ext like this:

dumpfmt.jar
gskikm.jar
ibmjcefips.jar
ibmjceprovider.jar
ibmjsseprovider2.jar
ibmpkcs11.jar
ibmpkcs11impl.jar
indicim.jar
jaccess.jar
JawBridge.jar

The jar which is glaringly missing is core.jar (for things like
java.lang.Object)

We get the following stack trace:

The javaw and launchingsupport.jar are all there and I can reproduce this 100%
on three different machines.

In one case, it turns out to be a user error. I had a Linux javaw sitting in 
the same directory as the javaw.exe.
marking as invalid. User configuration error.

I am still seeing this problem (which also seems similar to bug 70425).  It 
has occured for me very infrequently...  but several times.  The big problem 
is that once the installed JVM is created with the invalid jars, the JVM is 
always invalid - there appears to be nothing that the user can do to fix the 
situation.

After wading through the JDT source, I now have a theory as to the cause.  I 
see that the library info is persisted in libraryInfos.xml.  I found the file, 
and the entry for the library in question is: 

<libraryInfo home="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6\java\jre" 
version="???">
<bootpath>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\jre\lib\rt.jar"/>
</bootpath>
<extensionDirs>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6\java\jre\lib\ext"/>
</extensionDirs>
<endorsedDirs>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6\java\jre\lib\endorsed"/>
</endorsedDirs>
</libraryInfo>

In other words, it's mostly empty.  The other library info settings in the 
file were fully populated, as I'd expect.  I saved a copy of the file, deleted 
the above entry, and re-ran the WSAD (v6) build I'm using.  Making no changes 
to the definition of the VM itself, all I did was re-open the "installed VMs" 
preferences page, view the jars for the VM, and the correct jars are now all 
listed.  The LibraryInfos.xml file now contains

</libraryInfo>
<libraryInfo home="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6\java\jre" 
version="1.4.2">
<bootpath>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6\java\jre\lib\core.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\graphics.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\security.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\server.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6\java\jre\lib\xml.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\charsets.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\ibmcertpathprovider.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\ibmjaasactivelm.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\ibmjaaslm.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\ibmjcefw.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\ibmjgssprovider.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\ibmjssefips.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\ibmjsseprovider.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6
\java\jre\lib\ibmorb.jar"/>
<entry path="C:\wsad\builds\rad.0818\runtimes\base_v6

</endorsedDirs>

...which looks (and functions) much better.  Unfortunatly, this means that 
even on the same machine, using the same workspace and installed VM settings, 
the problem is not 100% reproducible.  However, I have a theory.  My machine 
(a thinkpad) is running very slow right now - I think the disk drive is 
failing.  I tend to run a lot on the machine, and when the drive is busy some 
simple operations can take a long, long time.  I'm hoping to get the machine 
fixed, but I think it's also representative of some slow, and perhaps short of 
memory (and thus thrashing) machines that we've seen customers use.  

Now, in org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.StandardVMType, the 
generateLibraryInfo method invokes the LibraryDetector class in a new VM, and 
expects the process to have completed in <10 seconds.  I can assure you that 
on my machine, on a bad (slow) day, starting a new process may take >10 
seconds (yes, it's horrible).  The problem is twofold: the loop in question 
silently times out and attempts to parse the result - no error is logged.  
Secondly, once the bad library info is written to the LibraryInfos.xml file, 
that's it - it does not matter if my machine was just having an anti-virus-
scan sort of moment, and running very slow for a short period of time - 
there's nothing that I can do to cause the VM to be re-invoked, and thus the 
settings corrected.

I don't think there's much you can do for when the machine runs slow - a 10 
second timeout seems reasonable.  However, if you timeout, I think it's a bug 
to persist that data.  You have no real data to persist, and doing so prevents 
any opportunity for me to retry after a reboot, or re-run the operation in any 
way.  This would still not be ideal, but at least the problem would become 
self correcting.  

I'll let you decide the best fix, but a very simple change would be in 
org.eclipse.jdt.internal.launching.LaunchingPlugin.  Change the 
getLibraryInfoAsXML method to not include any element for which info.getVersion
().equals("???").  This would then not persist the (bad) VM data, and thus re-
try the parsing the next time the workbench comes up (which will generally 
work).

Looking at the code, Tim's comment#5 looks like the correct diagnosis of the 
problem - i.e. a timeout occurred while attempting to generate library 
information for a VM install. Looking at alternatives.

Created an attachment (id=14335)
potential patch

Attaching potential patch. The fix logs an error and does not persist the
libraries when they could not be generated.

Created an attachment (id=14336)
zip file of patched plug-in

Zip file with patch plug-in applied to 3.0.1 stream.

Tim, can you please test with the patch in comment#9.

Luc, can you look at the proposed fix from comment#10 (also works in 3.1 
stream), and make any comments. My only concern is that the build path could 
get initalized wrong when the library detection fails, and then not update 
properly until the next workspace re-start. The libraries could be re-deteted 
at anytime, but this will not udpate the buildpath. However, since this is a 
rare occurrence, it seems reasonable.
Please verify, Luc. Released to 3.0.1 and 3.1 streams.
